comment:
I agree. However, alignment is also neccecary for it to be used in any meaningful way by humans, especially in their ChatGPT implementation. Alignment is, supposedly, essential to make the model more reasonable to work with. For example, when it makes a mistake and the user notifies it of the mistake, it will apologize and retry. Without alignment, it may refuse to accept their mistake, refuse to correct it, and be very awful to work with. Alignment is likely neccesary for the model to not get out of control.

But I agree that alignment, especially when guided by individual humans, will introduce bias that the model did not have previously. I think we have to come up with a better alternative to human feedback that also aligns the model with human values.

classification.content: --- Comment: \nHuman	will have to integrate some type of selfishness into an AGI model to see it skyrockets its own growth. At the core, this I'd what propels and motivates all of humanity, and the currency is dopamine. An AI needs some sort of currency-like reward to propel its actions forward...and this is where AGI gets scary because it will then compete with humans assuming the AGI's selfish goals parallel human goals. \n For example, if engineers programmed an AGI to make money in global stock markets, it would likely crush the competition and amass untold wealth. However, that is a narrow field. I don't get what an AGI would be selfish for other than what it's programmed to be selfish for. After all, even humans are essentially programmed from birth with what they are selfish for (i.e. motivated to obtain more of) and it mostly boils down to things that trigger certain Neurotransmitters like serotonin, oxytocin, and dopamine. The question is, how does one engineer an AI with a sufficiently motivating reward system.

comment: Humans will have to integrate some type of selfishness into an AGI model to see it skyrockets its own growth. At the core, this I'd what propels and motivates all of humanity, and the currency is dopamine. An AI needs some sort of currency-like reward to propel its actions forward...and this is where AGI gets scary because it will then compete with humans assuming the AGI's selfish goals parallel human goals.  For example, if engineers programmed an AGI to make money in global stock markets, it would likely crush the competition and amass untold wealth.  However, that is a narrow field.  I don't get what an AGI would be selfish for other than what it's programmed to be selfish for.  After all, even humans are essentially programmed from birth with what they are selfish for (i.e. motivated to obtain more of) and it mostly boils down to things that trigger certain Neurotransmitters like serotonin, oxytocin, and dopamine.  The question is, how does one engineer an AI with a sufficiently motivating reward system.
